This part holds the brain, ocelli, mandibles and eyes
as well as the glands that produce royal jelly.

This is made up of thousands of small tubes called
omatidia. They each project an image through a lens.
All the images are combined in the bee's brain.

This part is used to form wax into a comb and to groom
as well as to suck nectar from flowers.

This part of a bee's hind leg compresses the pollen
to make it easier to store while flying.

This part of the hind leg is broad and concave and
provides a holder for the pollen they collect.

This part anchors the legs and the wings.
It is filled with muscles for flight and movement.

There are four of these, although they look like two.
One hooks into the other for flight but separate
so the bee can get into tight spaces.

This part is covered with tiny hairs and allows the bee
to taste and smell as well as communicate and
sense air movement and temperature.

This part can expand and contract and change
shape for aerodynamics and balance.
It contains most of the internal organs.

These small openings on the sides allow air to enter
and, by expanding and contracting the abdomen,
feeds oxygen directly to the tissues.

These each have a single lens that may affect
stability during flight and help with geographical
orientation as they register light intensity.

This part, used only if the bee is threatened,
ends the bee's life.

This is where wax, used to make the
honeycombs, is produced.

These are what bees use to carry pollen and
comb it off their bodies. They're also used to clean
their antennae and for walking and landing.

Wings

There is only one Queen per hive.
The Queen produces all of the eggs as well as
chemicals that affect the behavior of other bees.

Drones are the males and their only
purpose is to mate with the queen.
They don't have stingers.

All workers are females.
They build the hive, clean it and forage for food.
They are the ones you see outside the hive.

Now click on the
Bee for fun facts!

you want to quit?
